awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Maintenance Planning for Complex Systems in  Dynamic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Equipment failures in capital-intensive industries, such as oil and gas exploration, aerospace, and power generation, may threaten human lives and have significant environmental and economic impact.  Many of these equipment failures can be traced to poor equipment maintenance.  One criticism of existing maintenance planning is that the existing predictive failure models do not accurately reflect degradation resulting from multiple causes in dynamic environments.  This project addresses the need for better planning models and analysis to enhance equipment reliability in capital-intensive industries.  The PIs have established collaborations with industrial partners to ensure the relevance of their research.  Educational opportunities for students, including outreach to underrepresented minorities, is also supported by the award.  

This award will support research on a general and systematic methodology for effective reliability modeling and maintenance planning for critical complex systems in capital-intensive industries.  To successfully accomplish the goal, four specific objectives will be achieved: (1) developing a broad class of general stochastic models that can integrally handle the complexities of degradation processes under dynamic environments; (2) constructing general stochastic-modulated multi-dimensional stochastic processes to model the multiple dependent degradation processes under dynamic environments; (3) creating a general mixture degradation framework to capture heterogeneities at both population and unit-levels; and (4) developing a unified maintenance decision-making framework that jointly integrates long-term maintenance planning and short-term dynamic decisions. Successful development of these models will lead to fundamentally new perspectives on the application of reliability and maintenance optimization for complex engineered systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of this collaborative-research award is to develop a general and systematic decision framework for reliability modeling and maintenance optimization strategies that provide fundamental insights for the successful development and operations of complex systems in capital-intensive industries (e.g., energy, oil and gas). The project has been successfully implemented following the collaboration plan and the timeline outlined in the proposal. Research findings from this project provide significant and applicable models and analysis tools that advance the accurate reliability modeling of complex systems and transform maintenance decision-making for capital-intensive systems. Broader economic impacts have been generated through optimized operational decisions in industrial implementation, such as enhanced reliability, improved productivity, and lower costs.

Intellectual Merit

In this project, we aim to develop a general and systematic decision framework for reliability modeling and maintenance optimization strategies that provide fundamental insights for the successful development and operations of complex systems in capital-intensive industries. One of the critical challenges facing these industries is how to improve the reliability performance of critical equipment at lower costs, and avoid disastrous failures caused by unreliable equipment (e.g., Deepwater Horizon oil spill). Yet existing reliability models/methodologies fall far short when addressing emerging concerns regarding reliability and maintenance of these complex systems. Traditional reliability studies do not adequately investigate problems related to multiple dependent failure processes, multi-level heterogeneities, and dynamic environments. Current maintenance models fail to provide satisfactory decision-support for efficient actions and resource allocation.

To address these challenges and achieve the project goal, we have implemented and completed the tasks proposed in this project and achieved four specific research objectives. (1) Develop a broad class of general stochastic models that can integrally handle the complexities of degradation processes under dynamic environments; (2) Construct general stochastic-modulated multi-dimensional stochastic processes to model the multiple dependent degradation processes under dynamic environments; (3) Create a general mixture degradation framework to capture heterogeneities at both population and unit-levels; and (4) Develop a unified maintenance decision-making framework that jointly integrates long-term maintenance planning and short-term dynamic decisions. To validate the developed models, we have worked collaboratively with industry partners where data and process knowledge are available. Research efforts in this project have led to 8 high-quality journal papers, 2 PhD dissertations, 10 conference papers, and 23 conference presentations.

Broader Impacts

This project supported three PhD students, including two female PhD students, and one female REU student. Students were exposed to reliability and maintenance problems in capital intensive industries such as oil and gas, refinery, and petrochemical. They were trained to conduct extensive literature review, study failure mechanisms of the complex systems, identify research problems, develop models independently, and solve problems using various probability, statistics, simulation and optimization methods. Students are encouraged to disseminate their research findings at conferences (e.g., INFORMS annual meeting, IISE annual conference, RAMS (Reliability and Maintenance Symposium), and MSEC (ASME Manufacturing Sciences and Engineering Conference)). The PI and her students have made a total of 23 conference presentations based on research works completed in this project. The research findings have also been added in course materials for the graduate-level courses (Stochastic Processes, and Decision Making under Uncertainty) taught by the PI, e.g., stochastic degradation process, sequential maintenance planning. The PI actively led and participated in various outreach activities, to inspire middle school and high school students’ interests in engineering.

The proposed work produces accurate reliability models and systematic maintenance decision-making support that can directly benefit decision-makers in capital-intensive industries. Broader economic impacts have also been generated through optimized operational decisions in proof-of-concept experiments in collaboration with industrial partners. The PI and her research team have closely collaborated with industrial experts, including Covestro (a chemical processing company), Delek (a refinery company), and NASA Ames Research Center. Various case studies were jointly conducted with the industry partners to demonstrate the proposed reliability and maintenance models, and results from the case studies were carefully examined and summarized in referred journal/conference papers. These industry collaborations promote a quicker transfer of technology into industries, and the industry feedback has further helped improving both research and curriculum development.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Yisha Xiang
